awd_titl_txt: Impacts of Education-Driven Urban Migration on Youth Aspirations and Identity
awd_abstract_narration:
Around the world, young individuals, especially those who are rural, first generation, indigenous, and racialized minorities, seek educational opportunities in cities to improve their lives. This temporary migration and resulting encounters with different people and ways of life in the city has countless unintended consequences particularly for those from marginalized groups.  As they leave their homes for major urban centers, they may experience increased exclusion but also may find new freedoms and a sense of cosmopolitan, national, and even transnational identity. As these youth complete their education or drop out, return to their homes or seek employment elsewhere, their migration experiences will alter relations between these members of marginalized groups and the nation-state. Geographers are well placed to investigate how young people from minority communities in remote regions experience urban migration and higher education; how they adapt to cultural difference and how this experience in turn affects their lives, their home communities and their understanding of belonging to the nation. This project will provide insight into crucial questions about how migration and higher education in the city informs the social aspirations and political identities of minority youth.

Through a multi-sited study of higher education-driven migration in South Asia, a region of critical geopolitical importance, this research will develop theoretical frameworks and methodologies for understanding a) the social and cultural impacts of migration for higher education ? both for students and home communities; b) how daily life in an urban university context shapes the individual, collective, and territorial understandings of minority identity; and c) the central role that higher education plays in youth politics. In addition to these conceptual contributions, this project will d) develop a new methodological approach for working with minority youth and building research capacity among this crucial population. Dr. Sara Smith and her research team will use focus groups, in-depth interviews, a household survey, and a participatory media project to meet these objectives. The project will advance Dr. Smith's geopolitics framework, which builds on advances in political geography to relate micro-scale experiences of daily life to macro-scale political phenomenon such as territorial conflict and nation-building. By bringing this framework to bear on migration, youth, and higher education, this project is expected to provide a new way to understand the relationship between minorities and the nation-state. The research will contribute to global geographies of higher education and political geographies of youth, encounter and cosmopolitanism.

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to understand the impact of higher education-driven migration on young people’s sense of self, politics, and ideas about what kind of future they want. Working with minoritized youth from the Indian Himalaya, the researchers conducted interviews, a survey, and a collaborative media project. Most participants in the project are religious and ethnic minority young people from Ladakh. A high altitude desert in the Indian Himalaya, Ladakh is about 11,000 feet above sea level. The Northeastern border is contested with China, and the Northwestern border is contested with Pakistan, and most Ladakhis who attend college are first generation students, going to large Indian cities, where they learn in their second or third language, and face racial and gender discrimination. Our project asked, how does this large scale migration shape their political attitudes, sense of self, and what they want for their communities?

 

The project generated more data than we have yet published on, but the intellectual merit and broader impacts have already come to fruition in a number of publications, events, and ongoing mentorship and other work. More than expected, the project has contributed to a “temporal turn” in geography, furthering work that seeks to understand the politics of time. That is, how do ideas about time (continuing the past, making a different future, managing the past by changing the behavior of young people), shape our politics. This project also contributed to our understanding and methods for understanding how young people intervene in urban settings, and how urban settings shape youthful life. Further, it helped develop a new agenda of research in South Asia that understands how “race,” apart from the Indian/white is made through historical events, political and social action, and the impacts that has on young people. Most of the people we talked to belong to state Indigenous categories, and are said to be different in appearance from “mainland” India, but these differences have not always been talked about as a process of racialization, or making racial identity. Our work furthered discussion and debate on the relationship between race and tribe in India, and informed a workshop and special issue on this topic.

 

The PI, postdoctoral research assistant, and the four graduate research assistants, have been writing and publishing together. This includes the qualitative research being the basis of part of one book, five journal articles, and two book chapters. However, in addition to this work based on the qualitative data, two writing collectives also came together from this work, which are more theoretical in nature. The first is the Against Colonial Grounds collective, which the PI (Sara Smith) founded together with GRAs Chris Neubert, Pallavi Gupta, and Lara Lookabaugh, along with Andrew Curley (University of Arizona). This has resulted in two publications thus far and an ongoing collaboration now involving additional faculty. This work revolves around how to connect different forms of colonial difference across contexts. The second is the Desirable Futures Collective, which is focused on temporal geographies. This includes the former Postdoc, Mabel Gergan, as well as Pallavi Gupta, Lara Lookabaugh, Carlos Serrano, and additional colleagues Pavithra Vasudevan (UT Austin) and Cait McMillan (also UNC). This collective has three special issues underway in Political Geography, Environment and Planning D, and ACME. We take up the question of how to think about the future across contexts and drawing on a variety of literature from Black Geographies and Indigenous Geographies to anticolonial and queer of color critique. In addition to these academic outputs, we also made a website based on a handmade magazine made by students participating in this project – it is available at https://lamocards.wordpress.com. We also held a public exhibit at our partner organization in Ladakh, the Ladakh Arts and Media Organization.

 

In addition to the intellectual merit, described above, this project has involved collaboration and mentoring, including ongoing connections between some of the students involved in the project, but also the research assistants employed in the project in Ladakh, including Rinchen Dolma and Rigzin Chodon. In the US, the postdoc provided significant training for one postdoc, now in her third year at Vanderbilt in the Asian Studies department, and four PhD students, one of whom has graduated and is now the agricultural advisor to Bernie Sanders on the Senate Budget Committee, and the remaining three who are close to finishing their PhDs at UNC – Carlos Serrano, Pallavi Gupta, and Lara Lookabaugh. All US-based RAs were scholars of color, first generation, queer, or otherwise from systematically excluded groups in the academy.

 

The project has also provided a great deal of teaching material used in particular by the PI and former postdoc in their teaching in political geography and Asian Studies.
